column8: Jérôme Lentin gives a testimony on the evolution of the Institute covering a period of almost forty years. He discovers the IFEAD and meets André Raymond in 1972 while studying Arabic at the CREA in Beirut. Holder of an Arabic aggregation, he obtained a post of pensioner at the IFEAD in 1976 and held the position of scientific librarian of the Institute from 1979 to 1984. While the IFEAD became Ifpo, Resides from 2008 to 2010 as a researcher in delegation to work on the project of a dictionary of dialect Arabic. The path of Jérôme Lentin gives him a privileged place to account for the different aspects of the evolution of the Damascus Institute. This interview, in spite of its mediocre sound quality, evokes the changes and reports of the staff of the Institute, the roles of the various directors (in terms of openness to Syrian society or organization of work), scientific orientations Or the different forms that the collection of archives could take during its presence. A specialist in dialectology, Jérôme Lentin also explains the difficulties he encountered in the practice of his discipline among the members of the scientific community and even towards a part of Syrian society. The interview concludes with suggestions from people who can be met for further investigation.

column8: Jacques Picard discovers the IFEAD as early as 1955, then under the responsibility of Nikita Elisséeff. At the time, he went to the Institute to learn Arabic. If he is to leave Damascus the following year because of the Suez Canal crisis, he will make regular visits from Lebanon in the early 1960s. While working in Cairo IFAO, he became friends with Thierry Bianquis; The latter will invite him to join the IFEAD from 1976 to work to publish the work of the Institute. Jacques Picard worked at the printing press and then became an active witness to the changeover to the computerization of the publishing department. From 1996 onwards, he served as Intendant of the Institute. Since his retirement in 2005, Jacques Picard regularly visits the Sahnaya depot to help with the replenishment of works. This interview provides a singular testimony for several reasons about the Institute: the age of Jacques Picard's relationship with The IFEAD offers a unique perspective on its history (in relation to changes in the country and changes in personnel). The informant tells the story of his ancestors at length. Throughout the interview, he constantly places it in a global historical context, giving then His vision of this past. Having carried out a great deal of historical research, he drew on his bases of understanding and found explanations as to the internal and external causes of Armenian misfortune (tendency to subjugation, pantanism, sociology). He is quite critical of historians, who, according to him, have not worked enough on the role of France in Anatolia between 1918 and 1922. He himself wrote a pamphlet, entitled & quot; All guilty ", expressing the results of his analyzes. He explains the course of his paternal grandfather, who died in 1918 in a battle, then his father: in exodus after the genocide, put in an orphanage, and then working at the opera of Yerevan in the 1930s (Of which he will bring back records still preserved by the informant). He married in Armenia, had a child, was engaged at the front during the second war and then taken prisoner in Germany. He entered a legion of the German army and came to Paris in 1948. The informant also tells the story of his mother. The informant succinctly recounts their life in the Cadet district, the Armenian quarter of the 9th arrondissement of Paris, where the preservation of culture within the community rubbed shoulders with the need for integration. His father having arrived later in France, he repeatedly expressed his chance to receive a good transmission of this culture. Especially the music, the songs (he sings two songs, one in Turkish and one in Armenian), and especially the language (which allowed him to translate recently Raffi's book "The Fool"). He speaks of the increasingly distant family relationships and the loss of language, which results from a process of assimilation, which does not favor relations with people of Armenian descent. He is proud of his identity (he feels Armenian), claims it and wishes to pass it on to his daughter. So he gave her an Armenian first name, taught her the language and made her aware of the collective story. After mentioning his belated rediscovery of this history and of this country, he speaks about his associative activism (SPFA), among others by means of donations and actions in favor of the recognition of the genocide. He recounts his various trips to Armenia in the 1990s and 2000s and analyzes the difficulties of the Armenian people in forming a nation. He expressed his concern about the current situation in the country: economically aided by the diaspora, marked by wars and corruption, threatened with loss of cultural identity and refusing to give Armenian citizenship to members of the diaspora. She is essentially interested in the testimony of the first informant on the Resistance of her brother. The first informant shows personal records to the interviewer. During the Second World War, the informant lived in the Old Port of Marseilles while her mother and her brother moved to Pertuis where they had family. She then lived in the Rafle of Marseilles during which she was deported to the sorting camp of Frejus. On his return to Marseilles, all the dwellings had been destroyed. She decided to join her mother and her brother in Pertuis at the end of 1943. The brother of the informant was resistant to Pertuis and died as a resistant in an accident created by the Americans. Ten men died that day and families were warned during the day. The informant speaks about her funeral and the emotion created by this tragedy. The mother of the informant often tried to discourage her son from being involved in the Resistance. In 1944, the informant began working at the Pertuis hospital as a nurse. She then took part in the medical care of the victims of the La Simone explosion. She remembers that there were arrests of Pertuisians during the war, as well as assassinations. The investigator reads the testimony of Gaston Gilly on the Resistance of Ropdolphe Santucci, the brother of the informant. The informants talk about the allied bombing of the Americans in France, especially those of Marseilles. The first informant comments on photographs and documents about her brother and explains his life before he enters the Resistance, notably his trade as a plumber learned in apprenticeship. At the end of the interview, the two informants talk about their nursing work at the Pertuis hospital., French
